DOC.HEAD: Ex-Counselor Sues Salvation Army Claiming Discrimination
DOC.TEXT: A woman who says she was forced to go outside her office to speak Spanish has filed a discrimination suit, charging her former employer's English-only policy insulted Hispanic employees. Ivette Gonzalez, a former probation counselor at the Salvation Army, contended she was forced to resign in 1986 for failure to abide by a ban on speaking of Spanish during breaks. ``They said the only way I could speak Spanish during lunch was to go outside the building,'' said Mrs. Gonzalez, 34, a native of Puerto Rico. ``I felt humiliated.'' Ms. Gonzalez said the policy caused heart palpitations and emotional distress. She is seeking more than $10,000 in damages and reinstatement or reimbursement for lost wages in the suit filed Monday in federal court. Her bilingual ability helped her get the job in 1986 with the Salvation Army, which supervises people on probation for misdemeanors. Two months later, center director Carroll Hepperle ordered employees to stop speaking Spanish except when conversing with a Spanish-speaking client, she said. Hepperle said English-only rule was issued because some employees heard nothing but Spanish and felt they were being talked about. Also, he had been told that some distasteful conversations were overheard by Spanish-speaking employees, he said. ``We're not here to discriminate against people. We're here to help people,'' he said.
